title: Malawi: Magnitude of Child Labour in Malawi Not Known
text:
Malawi: Malawi CSOs Petition UN On Human Rights Violations By George Bulombola 
Ntcheu — In the absence of updated statistics on child labour, the magnitude of the problem in Malawi is not known as the last cluster survey on child labour was conducted in 2002. 
Speaking in an interview with Malawi News Agency after closing a two day training on community child labour monitoring system in Ntcheu, Community Principal Labour Officer in the Ministry of Labour, Youth and Manpower Development, Francis Kwenda said it is difficult to measure results of different interventions which are being implemented to eliminate child labour in the country due to lack of updated statistics. 
He said labour ministry is working with International Labour Organization, Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation and Water Development, Winlock International and Japanese Tobacco International on programmes to eliminate child labour. 
He said government has a policy and other instruments geared at protecting children from child labour, but was quick to express concern over lack of enforcement of laws and such instruments. 
"Other challenges include inadequate human and financial resources, and unqualified labour inspectors at district level," he said. 
He then said there was need for child labour survey which can give a true reflection of the magnitude of child labour and measure the impact of various interventions. 
Also speaking in an exclusive interview with Mana, International Labour Organization Monitoring and Evaluation Officer, Gracious Ndalama concurred with Kwenda saying there is scanty information on child labour but expressed hope that government through the Ministry of Labour, Youth and Manpower Development and National Statistics Office would conduct the required survey before the end of the year. 
"About 29 per cent of children are in child labour in Malawi and most of these are in the agriculture sector. This sector employs children because children do not have negotiation skills, they are easily controlled and provide cheap labour," said Ndalama. 
Statistics indicate that child labour in Malawi has decreased to 29 per cent as of 2006 from 37 per cent as of 2002. Malawi
